verses.text: So Abram went up from Egypt to the Negev, he and his wife, and all that belonged to him, and Lot with him.
verses.comment: Abram leaves Egypt after the episode with Pharaoh, setting the context for his continued journey in faith. This mirrors the pattern of God's people entering and later departing Egypt (see Exodus 12:41).

verses.text: Now Abram was very rich in livestock, in silver, and in gold.
verses.comment: Abram's wealth demonstrates God's blessing upon those who trust and follow Him, echoing the later concept that faithfulness leads to spiritual riches, not just material ones (see Matthew 6:33).

verses.text: He traveled by stages from the Negev as far as Bethel, to the place where his tent had been at the beginning, between Bethel and Ai,
verses.comment: Returning to Bethel shows a pattern of spiritual renewal, revisiting the place where God was previously encountered. This demonstrates the importance of worshiping at consecrated places.

verses.text: to the place of the altar that he had made there earlier. There Abram called upon the Name of the LORD.
verses.comment: Abram offers worship at the altar. This emphasizes the centrality of sacrificial worship, a theme fulfilled in the ultimate sacrifice of Christ (see Hebrews 9:14).

verses.text: Lot, who went with Abram, also had flocks and herds and tents.
verses.comment: Lot shares in Abram’s blessing by association. This suggests the spiritual benefit that comes to those united in close relationship with the people of God (cf. Acts 16:31).

verses.text: But the land could not support them while they stayed together, because their possessions were so great that they could not remain together.
verses.comment: Material blessing brings the challenge of unity in community. Throughout Scripture, division over possessions foreshadows the necessity of peace and charity (see John 17:21).

verses.text: There was strife between the herders of Abram’s livestock and the herders of Lot’s livestock. The Canaanites and the Perizzites were dwelling in the land at that time.
verses.comment: The mention of Canaanites and Perizzites underlines the theme of pilgrimage and the challenge of living in a land not yet inherited. The need for peace within the community is emphasized over rivalry.

verses.text: So Abram said to Lot, 'Please, let there be no strife between you and me, or between my herders and your herders, for we are close relatives.'
verses.comment: Abram’s appeal to peace and unity among brothers foreshadows Christ’s call for unity among his followers (John 17:20-23).

verses.text: Is not the whole land before you? Please separate yourself from me. If you go to the left, then I will go to the right; or if to the right, then I will go to the left.
verses.comment: Abram’s generous offer reveals humility and trust in God’s providence. This self-emptying is a model of Christian charity, anticipating Christ’s teaching to put others first (Philippians 2:3-4).

verses.text: Lot lifted up his eyes and saw all the valley of the Jordan, that it was well watered everywhere—like the garden of the LORD, like the land of Egypt—as you go toward Zoar. (This was before the LORD destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.)
verses.comment: Lot is attracted by appearances, but the land he chooses is close to the wickedness of Sodom. Biblical wisdom often warns against judging only by appearances (1 Samuel 16:7; 2 Cor 5:7).

verses.text: So Lot chose for himself all the valley of the Jordan, and Lot journeyed eastward. Thus they separated from each other.
verses.comment: Lot’s choice marks a separation, echoing later moments when God separates his people for their spiritual good. There is a pattern in salvation history where choosing immediate gain leads to unforeseen spiritual peril (cf. Luke 12:21).

verses.text: Abram settled in the land of Canaan, while Lot settled among the cities of the valley and pitched his tents as far as Sodom.
verses.comment: Abram remains in Canaan, the land of promise. His faithfulness in remaining in the promised land contrasts with Lot’s proximity to sin. Living near wickedness can put one’s faith at risk (1 Cor 15:33).

verses.text: Now the men of Sodom were wicked and great sinners against the LORD.
verses.comment: The moral warning here underlines God’s call for his people to pursue righteousness and avoid cooperation with evil, a call repeated in both Old and New Testaments (see 2 Timothy 2:22).

verses.text: The LORD said to Abram, after Lot had separated from him, 'Lift up your eyes and look from the place where you are—northward, southward, eastward, and westward.'
verses.comment: This renewed promise shows God’s faithfulness. Separation precedes blessing, suggesting the spiritual principle that detachment for God’s sake brings a greater inheritance (cf. Mark 10:29-30).

verses.text: For all the land which you see I will give to you and to your descendants forever.
verses.comment: God’s promise to Abram’s descendants is everlasting. The promise of an eternal inheritance points beyond earthly land to a spiritual heritage—a theme fulfilled in Christ’s Kingdom (Galatians 3:16-29).

verses.text: I will make your descendants as the dust of the earth, so that if someone can count the dust of the earth, your descendants also can be counted.
verses.comment: This imagery of countless descendants spiritually prefigures the multitude of the redeemed who are spiritually children of Abraham through faith (Romans 4:16-17).

verses.text: Arise, walk through the land in its length and breadth, for I will give it to you.
verses.comment: Abram’s act of walking through the land anticipates later ritual acts of possessing what God has given. This bodily action has parallels in Christian liturgy, where faith is expressed physically as well as spiritually (see James 2:18).

verses.text: So Abram moved his tent and came to live by the oaks of Mamre, which are at Hebron, and there he built an altar to the LORD.
verses.comment: Abram’s building of an altar marks Hebron as a place of communion with God. Altars are a sign of true worship and covenant. The emphasis on worshiping God in specific places prefigures the Christian practice of sacred spaces (cf. Revelation 8:3).
